posts.name: Jake Garlits
posts.cooked:
My team is having a very weird issue with PathPlanner. We started using PathPlanner mirroring to build autos this past week. Because of how our shop is set up, it was easier for us to test our autos on the red alliance setup. We build our PathPlanner autos on the blue side of the field, and ran the mirrored red version to test and tune our new auto.

Last night, we got the auto dialed in and wanted to test it on a blue alliance setup, just to make sure it worked. When we tested the blue auto, it did not run the same as the red side. The first few paths of the auto worked correctly, but the last path did not. The final path drives to the middle of the field to grab a note, then ends in front of the speaker so we can shoot the note, but when we ran the auto on blue the robot drove way past it where was supposed to stop and crashed into the alliance wall.

I don’t understand why the red mirrored version of the path would work, but the blue version would not since the path is built on the blue side.

posts.name: Andy Gasser
posts.cooked:
Try running the path with PathPlanner Telemetry connected. It will help you understand what PathPlanner is telling the robot to do, and what it thinks the robot is doing.

Maybe it’s getting lost somehow (maybe you’re seeing an AprilTag), or the path is ending and you have a command at the end (shooting) that doesn’t do what you expect. If you share your code, we can try to help.

posts.name: Max Morehead
posts.cooked:
Are you simply feeding wheel odometry to pathplanner or do you have a vision-in-the-loop pose estimator? Do you have replanning turned on?

As always code and/or logs will improve responses, though your team is good enough that I’d understand why you wouldn’t want to release code.

posts.name: Jake Garlits
posts.cooked: I am heading into the shop now and can send a snapshot of the telemetry in a bit. Here is our code (FRC2024-40-Add-Auto-5 branch) and the auto in question is Auto5. It’s a pretty simple auto, just uses Paths and NamedCommands.

posts.name: Andy Gasser
posts.cooked:
In Path5.4 , your goal end state is not to be stopped. This could explain why the robot keeps going straight and bounces off the alliance wall. I can’t explain why that would only happen on the blue side though. image 796×143 2.99 KB

image 796×143 2.99 KB

image 796×143 2.99 KB

posts.name: Jake Garlits
posts.cooked: That was the issue, thank you! Silly mistake, not sure how that got set. Still confused as to why it stopped on red and not on blue though.

posts.name: Jake Garlits
posts.cooked: Another problem we are having is delayed auto. We put the warmup function into our code to try to fix it, but it doesn’t seem to be working right. Are we using it wrong?

posts.name: Andy Gasser
posts.cooked:
The delay could be because of the way you’re selecting and loading your autonomous command. The way you’re doing it, the path files aren’t loaded until autonomous starts. Loading a path can take up to a couple seconds. Robot.autonomousInit() calls RobotContainer.getAutonomousCommand() , which in turn calls AutoCommands.SelectAuto() .

Your SelectAuto() command is making a decision on which auto to choose, and then loading the path and creating the command. A way to optimize that would be to load all of your autos in the AutoCommands constructor, and then use the cached command in SelectAuto() instead waiting until auto starts to create it. The only downside to is that preloading will use more memory, since it will load all of the autos.
